question.title: Adapting the Stockfish chess engine in a Java application
question.body:
I have written Java code that replicates a chess game. For the UI, I have used Vaadin. I'm trying to integrate Stockfish to my code.

But from the below links. Link 1

Link 2

It seems like I have to run a software locally and then interact with a process. But I want the game to be standalone. So I'm not sure which system it will be used.

How will I resolve this? If I add all the three engines to my bundle, it will make it heavy.

Is it possible to get integrate as a library rather than running as a separate software? How?

answers.body:
Stockfish is a C++ programmed software so it's not simple to integrate into a Java code base. You have a few alternatives like Java Native Interface or Java Native Access but if you are not familiar with it, it can become quite complex for non trivial projects.
It could possibly be simpler to create a ProcessBuilder to launch the binary and use Input and Output readers/writers to manage the Stockfish out as it was being used from the terminal (send/write/type input and read the output/stdout/stderr).

A solution generally used by such applications would be to tell the user to install appropriate Stockfish binaries themselves (likely with a link to where they should get it from) and configure in your app where it is. But if you absolutely need your thing to be self-contained - then yeah, you'd have to ship binaries for all systems you support and detect what you're running on.
@Ale but how would is use it for every system, like Linux, WIn or MacOS? would i have to download all the 3?
